Tokiurada; Hodogaya-ku, Yokohama 240 (dapars) (Received August 31, 1881) Summer 'the catalytic oxidation of CO with E32 (393-509 K) over fixed Cr or Crz catalysts, prepared by the fixing reaction of Cr(n3-C3Ei6)3 or Cr2(173_ C3Hs)4 with surface OH groups of Si02, was studied to determine the structure and environment of active sites in terms of catalytic activities, activation energies, Racah parameters, ESR peak widths, photoluminescence and adsorptions of CO or 02. The monochromate structure fixed on originally acidic Ofd groups of the SiO2 surface pods easily rearranged by three redox treatments to form the surface cluster, Cr3+-O Cr3~- N with one vacant site on a Cr3' ion and with a suitable exchange interaction between the Cr3t ions. This rearranged surface showed a much higher activity than the virgin fixed Cr catalyst with mainly monochromate species, the fixed Cr2 catalyst with mainly dichromate species and a conventional impregnation catalyst. Introduction The surface nature of solid catalysis governing catalytic behaviour, to which much attention ha-s been paid [11, is generally heterogeneous and illdefined. This situation often gives ambiguous results regarding active sites and reaction mechanisms. Thus tailored catalysts with well-defined surface structures and properties may be useful to determine the origin of catalysis, to elucidate reaction mechanisms, and also to explore the essential factors for preparing good catalysts. Yermakov et al. [3] have demonstrated the advantage of anchored silica, catalysts prepared using various organometallic compounds. We have reported the design of well-defined structures on inorganic support surfaces using Mo(r23-C3~6)m [4] .c2(,73-C3Hs).C [5] a(Tt3-Css)3 [6] and Cr2(rt3C3H5)4 [7] as starting materials: over these active fixed catalysts the structures of active sites, the key factors for catalysis and the reaction mechanisms have been elucidated. In the present study, CO oxidation with 02 was chosen as a fundamental catalytic reaction, chemically related to a general oxidation mechanism. The preparation of the fixed chromium/silica catalysts and their catalytic activities for oxidation of CO with 02 are reported in comparison with those of conventional Cr catalysts. The structure and environment of active sites are also discussed. Catalysis by Cr catalysts for CO oxidation The oxidation of CO with 02 to form C02 over fixed Cr and Crz catalysts, the impregnation catalyst and two kinds of chromia gels was investigated in the temperature range 393 - 509 K in a closed circulation system (182 cm3). The fixed and impregnated catalysts were oxidized with 02 (60 torr) at 838 K for 1.5 h followed by evacuation for 1 h before each run. Two Cr203 gels were treated at 773 K. The C02 formation over the virgin fixed Cr catalyst (3) proceeded very slowly below 473 K in both the presence and the absence of O2. The rearranged fixed catalyst was found to have a much. higher activity than the virgin fixed Cr catalyst, the fixed CFZ catalyst or the impregnation catalyst (Fig. 5). The initial rates of the reaction on all catalysts employed were proportional to the partial pressure of CO in the range 8 - 28 torr but independent of the 02 pressure in the range 9.9 34 torn, as shown in Fig. 6. The activation energies (Fig. 7) were calculated to be 13, 22, 99, 4 and 85 kJ mol-1 for the rearranged fixed Cr catalyst, the fixed Cr2 catalyst, the impregnation catalyst, Cr2O3-a and Cr203-b, respectively. The similar fixation of Ma(n3-C3H6) or Mo2(n3-CsH3) has also been well defined [4, 5] . Ogasawara Department of Applied Chemistry, Faculty of Engineering, Yokohama National University, Tokiwadai, Hodogaya-ku, Yokohama 240 Japan * Author to whom correspondence should be addressed. The catalytic oxidation of CO with O2 (398–509 K) over fixed Cr or Cr2 catalysts, prepared by the fixing reaction of Cr(η3-C3H5)3 or Cr2(η3-C3H5)4 with surface OH groups of SiO2, was studied to determine the structure and environment of active sites in terms of catalytic activities, activation energies, Racah parameters, ESR peak widths, photoluminescence and adsorptions of CO or O2. The monochromate structure fixed on originally acidic OH groups of the SiO2 surface was easily rearranged by three redox treatments to form the surface cluster, with one vacant site on a Cr3+ ion and with a suitable exchange interaction between the Cr3+ ions. This rearranged surface showed a much higher activity than the virgin fixed Cr catalyst with mainly monochromate species, the fixed Cr2 catalyst with mainly dichromate species and a conventional impregnation catalyst.
